prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. A recipe for crispy rice treats results in a mixture that fills a 9-inch by 13-inch pan to a depth of one inch. If a crispy rice treats mixture resulting from 1.5 times the original recipe is poured into a pan that is 10 inches by 15 inches, to what depth, in inches, will the pan be filled? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest hundredth.
gpt_response:
To solve this problem, we will first calculate the volume of the original recipe in the 9-inch by 13-inch pan:

Volume = length x width x depth
Volume = 9 inches x 13 inches x 1 inch
Volume = 117 cubic inches

Next, we will calculate the volume of the mixture resulting from 1.5 times the original recipe:

Volume = 1.5 x 117 cubic inches
Volume = 175.5 cubic inches

Finally, we will calculate the depth of the pan when the 1.5 times the original recipe is poured into the 10-inch by 15-inch pan:

Volume = length x width x depth
175.5 cubic inches = 10 inches x 15 inches x depth
175.5 cubic inches = 150 inches x depth

Depth = 175.5 cubic inches / 150 square inches
Depth = 1.17 inches

Therefore, the pan will be filled to a depth of 1.17 inches when the mixture resulting from 1.5 times the original recipe is poured into the 10-inch by 15-inch pan.
